text: But
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The reasons under which that has been actually quite harmful to human communication is due to the inability to preserve what's known as context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And context is this term that is thrown around in academic language, and we want it to be very precise about its definition in the paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the definition that we give to context is information that is common knowledge amongst a set of people.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so what I mean by that is it's
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: known to be known and it's known to it's known to be known it's known to known to be known and it's known to be known to be known to know it's like this like iterative loop of everyone knows that everyone knows that everyone knows everyone knows something and to give a bit to give a couple of examples of that is when if i'm a doctor and i've read medical textbooks when i walk into a room with other physicians who i know have practiced medicine in the country that i'm in
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: it is common knowledge that they have a set of, they have this dictionary that we both share.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this dictionary that we share allows us to communicate incredibly efficiently.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As an example, if I had to walk into the operating room and had to explain to someone what some type of diagnosis meant every single time we walked into that room, it'd be incredibly inefficient to communicate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so because we have this shared context, but also because that context is common knowledge,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: it allows us to communicate incredibly efficiently.

text: And some would argue that context actually is the necessary components to communication.

text: even English itself would just be a set of symbols and words that didn't even make any sense to us, right?

text: Like the only reason that you understand what I'm saying is because we have this shared context and symbols aren't just these like random pieces of ink on paper, but because we're in them, we're able to communicate.

text: And so that's really important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Like we really want to protect context and to go back to why I brought up the internet and its inability to preserve context is because
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When we share information online today, specifically on social platforms, we don't preserve the context under which information was created.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: expectations, dispositions, and judgments that maybe that content wasn't initially intended to be communicated in.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so context today is actually very hard to preserve.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
